user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketListen_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketListen_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                             os_result;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    os_result = listen(impl->fd, 10);
    if (os_result < 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("listen: %s\n", strerror(errno));
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketListen_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragment in the provided function appears to modify the function parameter (the pointer token) or the pointer value itself. Details:
- The function parameter is declared as const OS_object_token_t *token, and there is no assignment to token, no increment/decrement, and no other operation that would change the pointer value.
- The only use of token is as *token in the macro invocation: OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(..., *token). This yields an lvalue referring to the object pointed to; the macro takes the address (&(tok)) and passes that address to OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, which accepts a const OS_object_token_t * and only reads token->obj_idx. No modification occurs.
- The macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET produces an address into the table and returns a pointer to OS_impl_file_internal_record_t; that pointer is stored in impl and used to call listen(impl->fd, 10). Neither token nor *token is modified.
- The code does not modify the object referred to by token either (only reads obj_idx), and modifying the pointed-to object would be allowed by Rule 17.8 in general; here it does not happen.
Therefore there are no fragments that require further investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
